title: How to Suppress the Gag Reflex

steps.title: Squeeze your thumb.
steps.content: Squeeze your thumb. Close your left thumb in your left hand and make a fist . Position your thumb under your fingers. Squeeze tightly without causing yourself too much pain. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Put a little table salt on your tongue.
steps.content: Put a little table salt on your tongue. Moisten the tip of your finger, dip it into some salt, and touch the salt to your tongue. Salt activates the taste buds on the front of your tongue and sets off a chain reaction that temporarily suppresses your gag reflex. [2] X Research source Another way to do this is to put a teaspoon (0.99 metric tsp) of salt in a glass of water and rinse your mouth with that. Don't forget to spit!

steps.title: Numb your soft palate.
steps.content: Numb your soft palate. When an object touches the soft palate, it can trigger the gag reflex. Use an over-the-counter (OTC) throat-numbing spray like Chloraseptic to desensitize your soft palate. Alternatively, you could gently apply a topical OTC analgesic with benzocaine using a cotton swab. The effects should last for about an hour, and your palate will be less reactive. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Throat-numbing sprays rarely cause side effects. However, you should stop using it if you experience vomiting , nausea , dizziness , drowsiness, and/or stomach cramps . [4] X Research source Use the benzocaine remedy with caution. The cotton swab could trigger a gag or choking reflex. Other possible side effects include fatigue, weakness, skin irritation around the ears, blue skin around the lips and fingertips, and shortness of breath . [5] X Research source You should avoid the benzocaine remedy entirely if you’re allergic to benzocaine. Ask your doctor or pharmacist about interactions with other OTC medications, vitamins/supplements, or herbal remedies you might be taking.

steps.title: Find out where your gag reflex starts.
steps.content: Find out where your gag reflex starts. You can do this by using your toothbrush to brush your tongue . The point nearest to the front of your tongue that makes you gag is where you should concentrate. [6] X Research source Don’t stick your fingers in your mouth. You might induce vomiting.

steps.title: Brush your tongue right where your gag begins.
steps.content: Brush your tongue right where your gag begins. Yes, you'll gag, and it will be unpleasant, but it won’t last long. Spend about ten seconds brushing that area (and gagging). Then call it a night. [7] X Research source Repeat the process over the next few nights in the exact same spot. Your gag should gradually decrease each time you do it.

steps.title: Increase the brushing area.
steps.content: Increase the brushing area. Once you can touch your toothbrush to the original starting point without gagging, it's time to move the toothbrush farther back. Try brushing ¼ to ½ inch (6mm–12mm) behind where your gag used to begin. Repeat the process as you did in the first spot.

steps.title: Move the brush farther back.
steps.content: Move the brush farther back. Do this each time you make progress desensitizing small areas in front. Keep moving it farther back until you've reached the farthest visible point of your tongue. Eventually, the toothbrush will come into contact with your soft palate, if it hasn't already.

steps.title: Desensitize everyday.
steps.content: Desensitize everyday. Be persistent. This process takes about a month to complete. Afterward, you should be able to have a doctor swab the back of your throat without gagging. You might have to repeat the process from time to time, as your reflex might return if you don't. [8] X Research source A good way to keep yourself desensitized is to brush your tongue regularly. Not only will it help quell the gag reflex, it’ll also give you fresher breath!

steps.title: Practice some form of meditation.
steps.content: Practice some form of meditation . Ask your dentist if you can wear earplugs to drown out the sound of equipment they’ll be using during your appointment. This will allow you to focus on calming thoughts and forget about the activity going on near your throat. If you think you might fall asleep, ask for a bite block to prop your jaw open. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Hum
steps.content: Hum . Humming keeps you breathing, which is essential for relaxation. It’s also difficult to gag and hum at the same time. Try this at the dentist’s office while you’re getting x-rays or having impressions of your teeth taken. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Raise one leg slightly.
steps.content: Raise one leg slightly. Do this while you’re sitting or lying in the dentist’s chair. Concentrate on keeping your leg raised. Switch legs if your first leg gets tired. This trick will distract you from the work going on in your mouth and near your soft palate. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Listen to music
steps.content: Listen to music . Ask your dentist if you can play your MP3 player during your cleaning or filling. Play songs that make your mind wander or interesting podcasts that demand your full attention. Either way, you’ll be too busy focusing on audio to notice what the dentist is doing. [12] X Research source
